On 17th March, about 2 o'clock, the prisoner came for a pint of split peas—my man served her, and I saw her tender a bad half crown in payment—I put the change down, she took it up in a harried manner, and left; I found it was bad; my husband went after her aud gave her in charge.
WILLIAM FRIEND . I am the husband of the last witness. I Went after the prisoner, and gave her in charge.
GEORGE BARR (Policeman, L 34). I took the prisoner—she was take to Lambeth police court, and discharged.

ELIZABETH KING . I am the wife of Henry King, of Evelin Street, Dept
ford, a china dealer. On the 27th March, the prisoner came, between 6 and 7 o'clock in the evening, for two plates, at a 1d. each, and gave my daughter a half crown—she gave it me, and I found that it was bad—I marked it; and gave ber in charge.
JOHN LOCKER (Policeman, K 295). I received the prisoner, and this half crown—she said she did not know it was bad; a gentleman gave it to her down the road.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These half crowns are both bad.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

493.
JAMES HOLLOWAY
, Breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Timothy M'Carthy, and stealing therein 4s. 6d., his moneys.

TIMOTHY M'CARTHY . I keep a beer shop in Providence Street, Rother
hithe, I reside there alone; I padlock the door when I leave, and take the key with me—I go out on Sundays to divine service, and for some Sundays when I came home I have missed money—on 28th March, I missed a half crown, and a florin from my trousers' pocket, in my bed room—I had left home about half past 10 o'clock, and came back about 11 o'clock—I afterwards saw it at the station—the prisoner has been in and out like other customers, and has done several things for me—if I wanted a pint of beer taken out, he would take it, but he was not in my service—this money (produced) I had marked.
Prisoner. I was in the habit of going in and out of the house, and waiting, for three months, and taking you coffee when you were in bed, and serving, and opening the house.

EDWARD BARKER (Policeman). In consequence of information, on Sun
day,28th March, I concealed myself in the prosecutor's house, when he went out; the prisoner came in and went up stairs, and when he came down, I came out from my hiding place and took him; he had fastened himself in with the padlock—I found the half crown and florin on him—he had 9s. 1d. altogether.
Prisoner. He was intoxicated; I have carried him up td bed several times.
GUILTY —The prosecutor stated that he had missed 18l. 10s., and a watch, and pair of boots.

p.hi: The following case was omitted from the New Court, Wednesday.

div1.p:
494.
WILLIAM CARDING (27)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Richard Cooke, with intent to steal.

GEORGE ROOTS (Police sergeant, D 7). At half past 12 o'clock, on the morning of 1st March, I was on duty in Orchard Street—I heard a noise in the Samaritan Hospital—I went back, got over a wall, and examined the premises—I found the place had been broken open—I came back and got assistance, and it the house I found the prisoner, apparently drunk and asleep—Igot him no—I am positive he was sober—I asked him what he was doing there—he said, "Nothing"—I asked him how be got there—he said he did not know—I found marks on the donation box corresponding with this knife which I found on the prisoner.

LOUIS RICHARD COOK . I am house surgeon there. I was called up about half past 12 o'clock—I went down, and saw the prisoner—my impression is, that he was not quite sober; he could not have been very drunk, or he could not have got in—I did not notice any smell of spirits.

JANE MOULTON . I am nurse in the Samaritan Hospital. I saw marks on the passage door on the next morning—it had been forced open—it was all right the night before—the panes of glass were all right on the Sunday night—Iknow the prisoner, his wife was in our service—I had seen the prisoner there.

Prisoner. My wife told you the night previous how I was situated. Wit
ness. She said you were very drunk.

GUILTY .*—
Confined Twelve Months.

p.hi: sat for a short time on Tuesday morning, April 13th, to pass

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 10TH, 1858.

Vol. xlvi. Page Sentence.

2

2a

3

viction.

4

5
Collins, Edwin... 149... Four Years Penal Servitude.

6
Sowerby, Henry... 163... Confined Nine Months from Con
viction.

7
Saunders, Frank Valentine... 169... Confined Two Months.

8
Thornhill, John Higdon... 186... Confined Six Months.

9
Flint, Henry... 191... Confined Two Months.

10
Elliott, Mary... 194... Confined Twelve Months from Conviction.

11
Blacketer, Thomas... 194... Confined Six Months.

12
Smith, John... 269... Conviction quashed; doscharged on recognisance..

13
Marsh, Charles... 304... Confined Two Months more (April, 1858).

14
Tizzard, Sarah... 372... Confined Twelve Months.

15
M'Hale, Edward... 443... Confined Nine Months.

16

17

18
